comment.author: 63186071@N00
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Historic Sydney, and we'd love to have all of your old Sydney photos added to the group.

comment.author: 8793648@N06
comment._content: You've put the wrong date in; should be 04/10/1890 (from your photo investigator).

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: Thanks for pointing that out, opsbooks, I've amended the date above.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Arthur Streeton "The railway station, Redfern" 1893 - www.artgallery.nsw.gov.au/work/7209/ And another photo of the same view from the Tyrrell collection - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2469669056/] The old Redfern Station seems to have been a popular subject.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: 4 October was a SATURDAY in 1890 www.easycalculation.com/date-day/day-of-year.php . And judging by the shadow directions and length, I would guess it was about 5 PM. Saturday evening rush hour!

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: Thanks for the info and the links to other images, beachcomberaustralia. Looks like it was very popular!

comment._content: Also Star Photo Co. (later, with electric trams) - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=413410

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: And anonymous (earlier) - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.pic-vn4313057

comment.author: 94424961@N00
comment._content: Beachcomber, the The Charles Bayliss photo linked is very interesting. As well as the two Baldwin tram motors, it shows one of the two Kitson tram motors that ran briefly in Sydney. Unlike the Baldwin motors, the Kitsons were complicated and underpowered, as such they were not a success.

comment.author: 94424961@N00
comment._content: This image www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.pic-vn43130 57 was presumably taken shortly after the George Street electrification opened. All the trams visible are C-class motor/trailer sets.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The interweb has become better in the last 50 (!) months since I posted the Arthur Streeton painting link above. See it in ultra-high zoomability, and click on the little man to visit it at the AGNSW - www.google.com/culturalinstitute/asset-viewer/the-railway...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
I think all the photographers and maybe Arthur Streeton were on top of the Murcott's Railway Family Hotel on the other side of Railway Square.  It had a flat roof and balustrade - a perfect place to promenade and park your tripod - 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4174797251/]

It is raining in Arthur Streeton's painting - maybe he sheltered by a window undercover downstairs!

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Streeton's painting doesn't have the same height perspective as all the photographs (IMHO!). I think he set up his easel on the pavement under the awnings.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Streeton was definitely lower;  I think on the first floor from the relative position of the gas lamps on the corner and in the middle (see note - getting a bit technical here!).  If he was on the ground floor the 'middle' lamp would surely appear higher than the 'corner' lamp - perspectively speaking ...

I am constantly amazed at Streeton's detail and accuracy.  It is really great to see from the painting that the horse-drawn buses and steam tram curtains were bright yellow; the tramway flagman with his red flag under the 'middle' lamp; also the horse poo slowly dissolving in the rain;  and Something Big was happening in the grounds of the Benevolent Asylum - a large tent or marquee ("Save the Asylum from Nasty Railway Developers" perhaps?!) - we might be able to find out which day in 1893 Arthur Streeton was there. And whether it was raining, or just a passing shower.
